In terms of realistic apocalyptic, asteroid, science fiction, movies Deep Impact is one of the most realistic. Realistic being relative to all of the other movies out there, the most obvious being Armageddon. Now in my humble opinion the Messiah is one of the nicest ships in all of science fiction mainly because it utilizes mostly real parts that exist today cobbled together TO SAVE THE WORLD! Now looking at the pictures I have determined a few mods make it possible to recreate. The Component Space Shuttle, Tiberdyne Shuttles, FASA parts, Bobcats American and Soviet Packs. Now here is the issue. How do I put it all together. Now I can spend a few hours in the VAB testing launching and maybe put it all together cheat and get the thing launched into orbit cheating. But I don't want to do that. I want it to be as realistic as possible and I want it to be functional. I also want to strap the ARM to the top or front and use it to redirect asteroids. That last part is optional but I want to realistically assemble this thing in orbit like they did in the movie. I suppose all the little bits are relatively simple but how do I launch what looks like Space Shuttle SRBs and Energia Boosters into orbit without using the fuel in them. Now I can use the SRBs from KSO because they are liquid but still how do you launch an SRB? So I am just looking for ideas and advice, pictures would be greatly appreciated and if someone has a mod or is making a mod for this I am very interested.

Many Thanks,

This could go a number of ways, but I think it would be most at home in the how-to section. So that's where it's going.

Even the biggest SRB, full, is only 22 tons. That's a pretty mid-sized payload in KSP. You can stick it on top of the launcher; it's kind of a long payload, but with some struts and a bit of care in the pitchover it'll be fine. Or you could strap a pair of rockets to either side of it, or you could build a 44 ton lifter to send both SRBs up at once.

As mentioned, put them at the top of the staging list so they don't fire themselves.

Alternatively, since solid boosters won't be that useful for orbital manouevres anyway - you really want more control - just right-click them in the VAB and empty the fuel, using them simply for structural and aesthetic parts. As the single longest part, the big SRBs are pretty handy for structural use. That's what I did with my space station, https://flic.kr/p/nvDyw2 .

Here's an example of the two boosters either side approach: https://flic.kr/p/nvmC9T These are empty SRBs, with other bits attached. I had to use some girderwork because the poles were built as subassemblies from the top, and I made sure I strutted them to each stage of the rocket. Even when it was like this in orbit, https://flic.kr/p/nvmH8F, it stayed solid thanks to the struts and handled smoothly. The principle should work for full SRBs, you'd just need a more powerful rocket.

I would build it in 3 sections, the first I will call the main drive section, which is the three tanks and SRBs at the rear. The center section (the utility/living section) is everything aft of the shiny silver thing in your third picture. The command section is everything in front of that. I would use Sir. Docking ports for all of it.

Also, don't worry about sending it up empty. (This might be preferred) you can refuel in space.

I would also get KAS so you can hold the thing together with it's EVA placeable struts.

I built my own version. Took 7 launches. The docking platform in 2, then the crew cabin/scout ship, then the main body, then an RCS tanker, then a fuel tanker, and finally a stock space shuttle with the crew. Docking platform is not very accurate, and it's not to scale of the one in the movie (impossible using stock parts, even the SLS parts are too small), but I am happy with it. Now to see if it can catch asteroids! Or just blow up in orbit.

BTW, the Messiah it's self is a little over 400 tons fully fueled. The fuel tanker I built was absolutely insane. Over 3000 tons, as much power as the Saturn V 1st stage (slightly more actually, mechjeb helped with finding this out, and getting the beast into orbit), and it alone cost $1.2 million funds. It was laggy as hell launching it until the last set of boosters were jettisoned. The whole mission is over 2.2 million funds.

Here's a screenshot of the massiveness. Not the biggest thing I've built, but the biggest single ship for sure. No idea if she'll fly, but she looks pretty.
